de.esoco.lib.app

Class CommandLine

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.app.CommandLine

  • public class CommandLine
extends java.lang.Object
    Parses a command line and provides access to the options and the optional option values of the command line. If only the parsing of a command line is needed the static methods of this method can be used.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static java.lang.String DEFAULT_OPTION_PATTERN
      The default pattern for option arguments.
      static java.lang.String EXTRA_ARGUMENTS
      The key that can be used to query the remaining arguments that didn't match the command line options pattern.

    • Field Detail

      • EXTRA_ARGUMENTS

        public static final java.lang.String EXTRA_ARGUMENTS
        The key that can be used to query the remaining arguments that didn't match the command line options pattern. The datatype is a list of strings that is always present, but may be empty.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DEFAULT_OPTION_PATTERN

        public static final java.lang.String DEFAULT_OPTION_PATTERN
        The default pattern for option arguments. Allows arbitrary case-insensitive command line options (if they fulfill the regular expression pattern "\\w|\?") of the form -<option>[=<value>] (the prefix '/' can be used instead of of '-').
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • CommandLine

        public CommandLine(java.io.InputStream rArgsStream)
        Creates a new command line from an input stream in Java properties file format. Boolean values will be converted to Boolean objects, all other argument values will be stored as strings.
        Parameters:

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If accessing the stream fails

      • CommandLine

        public CommandLine(java.lang.String[] rArgs,
                   java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> rAllowedOptions)
        Creates a new CommandLine object with a standard argument pattern that allows a certain set of options. If the allowed options are not empty the corresponding pattern will be created by invoking createStandardPattern(String[]). Otherwise the DEFAULT_OPTION_PATTERN will be used.
        Parameters:
        rArgs - The command line arguments
        rAllowedOptions - A list containing all the options that are allowed on the command line
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If one of the arguments is invalid

      • CommandLine

        public CommandLine(java.lang.String[] rArgs,
                   java.util.regex.Pattern rArgPattern,
                   java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> rAllowedOptions)
        Creates a new command line instance. Parses the command line with the static parse() method.
        Parameters:
        rArgs - The command line arguments
        rArgPattern - The pattern to parse a single command line option or NULL for the default pattern
        rAllowedOptions - A list containing all the options that are allowed on the command line
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If either the argument pattern or an argument is invalid

    • Method Detail

      • createPattern

        public static java.util.regex.Pattern createPattern(java.lang.String sPrefix,
                                                    java.lang.String sAssignment,
                                                    java.lang.String... rAllowedOptions)
        Creates a command line pattern from a list of allowed option names. All parameter values may contain regular expression elements like character classes as long as they don't conflict with the regular expression requirements of the parse() method. That means especially that they must not contain capturing groups as these are used to find options and their values.

        To make the assignment of a value to an option mandatory the assignment token must be appended to it. For example, to enforce that option '-value' gets a value assigned, use the string 'value=' (if the assignment token is'=').

        If the list of allowed options is emtpy and a command line is parsed with the resulting pattern, any option will cause an exception to be thrown.

        Parameters:
        sPrefix - The allowed prefixes for an option
        sAssignment - The string or character used to assign a value to an option
        rAllowedOptions - A list containing all the options that are allowed on the command line
        Returns:
        A new pattern based on the method arguments

      • createStandardPattern

        public static java.util.regex.Pattern createStandardPattern(java.lang.String... rAllowedOptions)
        Creates a standard command line pattern from a list of allowed option names of the form -<option>[=<value>] (the prefix '/' can be used instead of of '-'). Based on the method createPattern(String, String, String[]).
        Parameters:
        rAllowedOptions - A list containing all the options that are allowed on the command line
        Returns:
        A new pattern based on the method arguments

      • readArguments

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> readArguments(java.lang.String sFileName)
        Tries to read the command line arguments from a Java properties file.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        A map containing the arguments as read from the file
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the file doesn't exist or could not be read

      • readArguments

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> readArguments(java.io.InputStream rArgsStream)
        Reads the command line arguments from an input stream in Java properties file format. Boolean values will be converted to Boolean objects, all other argument values will be stored as strings.
        Parameters:
        rArgsStream - The input stream to read the arguments from
        Returns:
        A map containing the arguments as read from the stream
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If accessing the stream fails

      • getArguments

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getArguments()
        Returns the arguments of this command line that are not options. The returned list contains all arguments that didn't match the options pattern as they appeared in the original command line. If no such arguments exist the list will be empty.
        Returns:
        The list of unparsed arguments (may be empty but will never be NULL)

      • getInt

        public int getInt(java.lang.String sOption)
        Convenience method that converts the result of getOption(String) to an integer value.
        Parameters:
        sOption - The option name
        Returns:
        The integer value or -1 if the option doesn't exists
        Throws:
        CommandLineException - If the option cannot be parsed as an integer

      • getOption

        public java.lang.Object getOption(java.lang.String sOption)
        Returns the value of a certain option. If the option exists but has no value (i.e. a switch option) the result will be Boolean.TRUE. If the option doesn't exist in this command line NULL will be returned. The method hasOption(String) also allows to check if an option exists.

        This method is case-sensitive. If an application has created the command line to be case-insensitive (e.g. by using the default pattern) it must always invoke this method with lower case option names because all option names have been converted to lower case on creation.

        Parameters:
        sOption - The option to query
        Returns:
        The option value or NULL for none

      • getString

        public java.lang.String getString(java.lang.String sOption)
        Convenience method that converts the result of getOption(String) to a string.
        Parameters:
        sOption - The option name
        Returns:
        The option string or NULL for none

      • hasOption

        public boolean hasOption(java.lang.String sOption)
        Checks if a certain option exists in this command line. This method is case-sensitive. If an application has created the command line to be case-insensitive (e.g. by using the default pattern) it must always invoke this method with lower case option names because all option names have been converted to lower case on creation.
        Parameters:
        sOption - The option to check
        Returns:
        TRUE if the option exists

      • parse

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> parse(java.lang.String[] rArgs)
        Parses a list of command line arguments into a map with the default argument pattern that allows arbitrary case-insensitive options.
        Parameters:
        rArgs - The list of command line arguments
        Returns:
        A new map containing all command line options together with their values; will be empty if the argument list is empty
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If one of the arguments is invalid

      • parse

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> parse(java.lang.String[] rArgs,
                                                              java.util.regex.Pattern rArgPattern)
        Parses a list of command line arguments into a map. Each element in the rArgs array will be matched against the given regular expression pattern. If the pattern matches the first group in the pattern will be considered to be a command line option and stored in the result map as a key. If the matched pattern contains another group it's string value will be converted by invoking TextUtil.parseObject(String) and the result will be stored in the map as the value associated with the key (= the command line option). If the pattern contains only a single group the value associated with an option will be Boolean.TRUE.

        To allow correct parsing of the arguments the argument pattern must contain at least one capturing group that identifies the name of the option. If options are allowed to have values a second capturing group must define the option value. It is possible for the pattern to contain more than two groups, but a maximum of two groups must be valid (i.e. not NULL). These two groups will then be used as the option and it's value, respectively.

        The pattern's flag CASE_INSENSITIVE controls if similar options with different case are to be distinguished. The default pattern allows arbitrary case-insensitive command line options of the form -<option>[=<value>] (the prefix '/' can be used instead of of '-').

        The returned map will contain the options in the same order they appear in the argument list. If the same option appears multiple times in the command line the value of the last occurrence will be contained in the result map.

        If the default option pattern is used any values on the command line that don't match the option pattern will be placed in a List of unparsed arguments that is stored in the returned map under the key EXTRA_ARGUMENTS. This list will always exist but may be empty.

        Parameters:
        rArgs - The original command line arguments
        rArgPattern - The pattern to parse a single command line option or NULL for the default pattern
        Returns:
        A new map containing all command line options together with their values; will be empty if the argument list is empty
        Throws:
        CommandLineException - If an argument cannot be parsed

      • requireOption

        public java.lang.Object requireOption(java.lang.String sOption)
                               throws CommandLineException
        Returns a mandatory command line option without validation.
        Throws:
        CommandLineException
        See Also:
        requireOption(String, Predicate)

      • requireOption

        public java.lang.Object requireOption(java.lang.String sOption,
                                      de.esoco.lib.expression.Predicate<java.lang.Object> pIsValidOption)
                               throws CommandLineException
        Returns a mandatory value of a command line option and optionally that it fulfills certain criteria that are asserted by applying a predicate. If the option value doesn't exist or the predicate yields FALSE for it an exception will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        sOption - The command line option to return the value of
        pIsValidOption - An optional predicate to apply to option values or NULL for no validation
        Returns:
        The validated command line option
        Throws:
        CommandLineException - If the option value doesn't exist or cannot be validated

      • requireString

        public java.lang.String requireString(java.lang.String sOption)
                               throws CommandLineException
        Returns a mandatory command line option as a string value.
        Throws:
        CommandLineException
        See Also:
        requireOption(String, Predicate)
